1: On 2023/10/16, I came home feeling tired and under the weather with a scratchy throat. That night, I experienced shivering and achiness. The next day, on 2023/10/17, I did a COVID rapid antigen test that was expired but showed a strong positive result. I had symptoms such as no appetite, sore throat, high fever up to 39.5°C, body aches, and excessive sleep. On 2023/10/18, I felt slightly better with reduced fever and aches, but the fever would occasionally rise to around 38.5°C without medication. I developed a runny nose, congestion, cough, and had a nosebleed. I slept for about 12 hours that night. Today, on 2023/10/19, I felt somewhat improved with less nasal discharge, a lingering cough, and sore throat. The fever seemed to have subsided but occasionally reached 38.2°C. I still experienced fatigue, body aches, occasional chills, and had two more nosebleeds. The COVID test remained strongly positive.

0: Hi there! I am a 19M from the United Kingdom, a non-smoker, weighing 220lbs, and standing at 6ft 0in. 1: I contracted COVID-19 on 2020/03 and tested positive on 2020/04/16. 2: I completely lost my smell and taste, was breathless, lethargic, fatigued, and had an awful cough. 3: I recovered from the virus on 2020/05/15, and my smell and taste were completely back to normal (although I now hate the taste of chocolate; that's the only thing that's different). 4: However, over 4 months after contracting the virus, I have noticed my smell (which has been completely normal since 2020/04/30) is massively changing. 5: I noticed it first on 2020/07/14 when chopping an onion, and it smelled really fruity and spicy rather than like...you know...an onion smell. 6: Over the last two days since this, I have noticed that everything is changing smells. 7: Cut grass now smells like poop, and food now smells like burning rubber. 8: It is different from how my smell changed when I contracted COVID-19 (I just woke up one day having completely lost my smell and taste), whereas this is just everything changing. 9: My question would be, is it common for smell to still be affected after so long of not having the virus, or should I be concerned I have it once again?

0: On 2021/08/15, I was notified that a colleague I had worked closely with tested positive for Covid-19. Concerned, I decided to get tested at a local clinic. 1: On 2021/08/16, I started feeling unwell with a sudden loss of taste and smell, followed by nasal congestion and a sore throat. 2: The next day, I received a positive test result. I immediately informed my family and workplace, and began isolating at home to prevent spreading the virus to my partner and our two kids. 3: Initially, I managed my symptoms with over-the-counter medications and rest, but within a few days, I developed a high fever and severe fatigue. 4: I contacted my doctor for advice. After a telehealth consultation, she recommended I monitor my oxygen levels closely and continue home care. 5: Despite following her advice, my symptoms worsened significantly by 2021/08/21. I had trouble breathing and called for an ambulance to take me to the hospital. 6: At the hospital, I was given monoclonal antibodies and placed on oxygen therapy. The medical staff closely monitored my condition. 7: After ten days of intensive treatment, my health began to improve, and I was discharged on 2021/08/31 with a detailed home care plan. 8: Back home, I continued to struggle with lingering symptoms like brain fog and a persistent cough. My doctor arranged for telehealth follow-ups to monitor my recovery. 9: To help with my long Covid symptoms, I started physical therapy and engaged in breathing exercises. 10: Throughout this period, my partner and family were incredibly supportive, helping with daily tasks and providing emotional support. 11: Once I fully recovered, I got vaccinated as soon as I was eligible, following the recommended schedule to ensure maximum protection against future infections. 12: Getting vaccinated and participating in a Covid-19 survivor support group helped me regain my confidence and provided additional peace of mind.
